channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: What It’s Like to Be the First Person Eliminated on ‘Survivor’
item.description: These are the contestants who train for months, only to be voted off in Episode 1. As the show’s 50th season begins, we ask about their head-spinning turns.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams

item.title: Epstein Effort to Finance a Dick Cavett Film Undone by Background Check
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein joined Mr. Cavett’s wife in an effort to create a PBS documentary on the talk-show legend. But then the producers did a background check on the financier.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi and Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: Dick Cavett had an illustrious career as a talk-show host known for his probing interviews. When a documentary about him was in the early stages, Jeffrey Epstein took an interest.

item.title: The Brooklyn Park Where Dozens of Snow Sculptures Bloomed
item.description: As the blizzard surged, a garden of snow sculptures arose in a Brooklyn park — a testament to New York creativity.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tyrone Delaney and Zachary Small
item.media:credit: Michael Tyrone Delaney for The New York Times

item.title: After ‘Love Island,’ Rob Rausch Was Wary of ‘The Traitors’
item.description: The Alabamian who is now a seasoned veteran of reality TV talks about sports, strategy and overalls (“just a great piece of clothing”).
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

item.title: ‘Scream 7’s’ Matthew Lillard is a Fan Favorite. If Only Hollywood Understood.
item.description: After a period of joblessness when he had to sell his home and cars, the “Scream” actor’s career is booming — whether Quentin Tarantino likes it or not.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer
item.media:credit: Adali Schell for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I am the best kept secret in Hollywood because the reality is, I go to conventions and my lines are crazy long,” Lillard said.

item.title: 5 Great Specials to Stream This Winter
item.description: Taylor Tomlinson, Kevin Nealon, Chris Spencer, Isabel Hagen and Jackie Kashian deliver very different but very funny hours to get you through the cold.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: Mitski, Raye: 9 Songs We’re Talking About This Week
item.description: Mitski ponders a breakup, Raye recalls a great heartbreak and Gnarls Barkley previews its farewell album.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles

item.title: I Needed ‘Heated Rivalry’: Gay Romance Minus the Tragedy
item.description: After a lifetime of settling for shame, secrecy and death onscreen, I had my doubts about “Heated Rivalry.” Then it seduced me, too.
item.dc:creator: Wesley Morris

item.title: How ‘The Pitt’ Grosses You Out
item.description: The medical drama tests viewers with protruding bones, visible organs and buckets of blood. Here’s how makeup and effects artists created seven gory afflictions.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: TMZ Drives Celebrity News. Thank This L.A. Intersection.
item.description: The website known for breaking news about famous deaths and juicy scandals has a name with roots in old Hollywood.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: The celebrity crime, courts and gossip site TMZ has delivered Los Angeles-centric scoops since 2005, when it was founded by Harvey Levin.

item.title: ‘Paul McCartney: Man on the Run’ Tells One Side of the Story
item.description: The Morgan Neville-directed film relies on new and archival interviews to cover familiar ground: the years after the Beatles broke up.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Paul McCartney: Man on the Run (Movie)

item.title: Watch the Final Scene of ‘Train Dreams’
item.description: The director Clint Bentley discusses the conclusion to his film, which stars Joel Edgerton and is an Oscar nominee for best picture.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Melissa Auf der Maur, a ’90s Rock Linchpin, Is Spilling Her Stories
item.description: The bassist and photographer who logged time in Hole and Smashing Pumpkins unpacks one of the most creative and chaotic times of her life in a new memoir.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Lucia Bell-Epstein
item.category: Even the Good Girls Will Cry: A '90s Rock Memoir (Book)
item.media:credit: Lucia Bell-Epstein for The New York Times

item.title: Delroy Lindo on ‘Sinners,’ the Oscars and the Power of Affirmation
item.description: In a career of standout performances and dispiriting lows, Lindo, 73, has held firm to his goal: “I want to be respected for my work.”
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Cruz and Marcus Maddox
item.media:credit: Marcus Maddox for The New York Times

item.title: ‘One Battle After Another’ Wins Producers Guild Award. Is Oscar Next?
item.description: The Paul Thomas Anderson film also took the top Directors Guild prize as well, a good sign for the movie’s best picture prospects at the Oscars.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
item.media:description: Paul Thomas Anderson, who, along with Sara Murphy, won the PGA for “One Battle After Another.”

item.title: How the BAFTAs Bungled Its Response to a Racial Slur
item.description: The awards show didn’t mention racist slurs when it told the audience that a man with Tourette’s might make “involuntarily noises.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:credit: Scott A Garfitt/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The executive producer of the BAFTAs ceremony said that one racist slur was edited from the BBC’s broadcast but that another was missed.

item.title: A Sports Frenzy for the Most Valuable Influencers
item.description: To reach young audiences raised on social media, leagues are giving content creators access to marquee moments.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: More people watched a flag-football game that featured content creators like Druski and was shown on YouTube than the Pro Bowl with actual N.F.L. superstars.

item.title: San Francisco Ballet Pulls Out of Kennedy Center Performances
item.description: The ballet company, one of the country’s most prestigious, had been under pressure to cancel its shows amid President Trump’s takeover of the performing arts center.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

item.title: Diya Vij Is New York’s Next Culture Czar
item.description: Diya Vij, the incoming commissioner of the Department of Cultural Affairs, said she wanted to make “open, accessible and sometimes radical cultural activities possible.”
item.dc:creator: Aruna D’Souza
item.media:credit: Marcus Maddox for The New York Times
item.media:description: Diya Vij, New York’s next commissioner of the Department of Cultural Affairs. Mayor Zohran Mamdani called her “a visionary and deeply thoughtful leader who understands that art is not ornamental to this city — it is essential to it.”

item.title: Thrilling Slasher Books for ‘Scream’ and Horror Fans
item.description: These 13 bloodthirsty tales will keep you up at night with clever thrills and heart-pounding action.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Graham Jones

item.title: Cambodia Celebrates the Return of Looted Artifacts from Tainted Dealer
item.description: The dealer, who died in 2020, had been accused of selling illegally excavated treasures of the Khmer culture. His estate returned dozens of them this week.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg
item.media:description: Cambodian officials with Khmer cultural artifacts that were returned to the country at the National Museum in Phnom Penh on Friday.

item.title: Neil Sedaka: 14 Essential Songs
item.description: The singer and songwriter, who died on Friday at 86, gave voice to teenage dreams, then executed one of music’s most unexpected comebacks.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Thomas Erlewine
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neil Sedaka at home in California last summer, when he was playing a residency at a lounge called Vitello’s.

item.title: Neil Sedaka, Singing Craftsman of Memorable Pop Songs, Dies at 86
item.description: He sang and co-wrote some of the definitive teenage anthems of the 1950s and early ’60s, including “Breaking Up Is Hard to Do,” and then reinvented his career in the ’70s.
item.dc:creator: Peter Applebome
item.media:description: Neil Sedaka performing onstage in London in 1977. He intersected in his career with a remarkably diverse array of musicians.

item.title: This Year, It Will Be the ‘Trump Kennedy Center Honors’
item.description: Despite plans to close the building this summer for a two-year reconstruction project, the renamed ceremony will be held elsewhere, the center’s president said.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: President Trump hosted the Kennedy Center Honors last year after installing himself as the institution’s chairman.

item.title: Iris Cantor, Philanthropist and Art Collector, Dies at 95
item.description: She and her husband, the financier B. Gerald Cantor, amassed one of the largest private collections of Rodin artworks, donating much of it to museums around the world.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Iris Cantor in 2001. A former model and stockbroker, she joined the bond brokerage firm Cantor Fitzgerald in 1967 and later married the founder, B. Gerald Cantor.

item.title: Sondra Lee Dies at 97; Originated Roles in ‘Peter Pan’ and ‘Hello, Dolly!’
item.description: With her frenetic energy and 4-foot-10 frame, Ms. Lee seemed destined to play a certain kind of stage character: excitable, endearing and charmingly scheming.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Sondra Lee in 1951. She came to public attention in 1954, when the influential choreographer and director Jerome Robbins cast her as the Native American princess Tiger Lily in his musical version of “Peter Pan.”

item.title: Review: ‘Gala Flamenca’ Brings New Blood and Traditional Thrills
item.description: The centerpiece of the annual Flamenco Festival New York saw the introduction of another wonder in Juan Tomás de la Molía, alongside some veterans of the art.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert

item.title: Review: Robert Rauschenberg’s Sharp Dancing Mind on Display
item.description: The Trisha Brown Dance Company is presenting a stellar double bill of Rauschenberg-designed works by Merce Cunningham and Trisha Brown.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas

item.title: Review: Harpist Parker Ramsay Merges Old and New With Friends
item.description: The multifaceted musician Parker Ramsay assembled an evening of Baroque and contemporary music, including a premiere by Georg Friedrich Haas.
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: ‘Chinese Republicans’ Review: These Women Are Playing to Win
item.description: Alex Lin’s new play focuses on four ambitious climbers of the corporate ladder. But their success comes at what cost?
item.dc:creator: Tim Teeman
item.media:description: From left, Jodi Long, Jennifer Ikeda, Anna Zavelson and Jully Lee in the play “Chinese Republicans” at Roundabout Theater Company’s Laura Pels Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month brings a malign quarterback, a naughty robot hottie and the grim reaper himself.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: In the Blink of an Eye (Movie)

item.title: Are Germany’s Top Cultural Events Becoming Impossible to Run?
item.description: A dispute over free speech at the Berlin Film Festival around Israel’s actions in Gaza, and rumors of the festival director’s firing, raised broader worries about Germany’s cultural landscape.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Rogers
item.media:description: Tricia Tuttle, the Berlin Film Festival director, was the subject of media speculation this week after several prize winners criticized Israel at an awards gala.

item.title: Chris Fleming Uses Dance to Make Us Laugh in His HBO Special
item.description: The kind of performer other stand-ups rave about, Chris Fleming turns to choreography to land jokes in his new HBO special.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Vincent Tullo
item.category: Chris Fleming: Live at the Palace (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Murder in Glitterball City’ and True Crime’s Obsession With Location
item.description: The two-part documentary on HBO is not just the story of a gruesome murder, but a portrait of the city, neighborhood and home where it happened.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.category: A Dark Room in Glitter Ball City: Murder, Secrets, and Scandal in Old Louisville (Book)
item.media:description: The home in Louisville, Ky., where James Carroll was murdered, as seen in the HBO documentary “Murder in Glitterball City.”

item.title: ‘Scream 7’ Controversies: What You Need to Know
item.description: The franchise’s latest edition ran into trouble on the way to the screen. Here’s what happened.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: ‘DTF St. Louis’ Review: Sex, Death and Jamba Juice
item.description: Steven Conrad (“Patriot”) brings his oddball sensibility to the limited-crime-series genre for HBO.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.media:description: Jason Bateman, left, and David Harbour play unsatisfied suburbanites in “DTF St. Louis.”

item.title: Resident Evil’s ‘Addictive Fear’ Is Keenly Calibrated
item.description: To go beyond jump scares, the director of Resident Evil Requiem has learned from “Weapons,” “The Shining” and “The X-Files.”
item.dc:creator: Harold Goldberg

item.title: 27 New Books to Read in March: Tana French, Liza Minnelli, Cat Sebastian and More
item.description: Novels by Tana French, Yann Martel and Cat Sebastian; memoirs by Christina Applegate and Liza Minnelli; a Judy Blume biography and more.

item.title: ‘Train Dreams' | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director Clint Bentley narrates a sequence from his film starring Joel Edgerton.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Late Night Lampoons Trump’s State of the Union Ratings
item.description: Stephen Colbert joked that the president “is really dragging down broadcast television” with lower ratings for Tuesday’s State of the Union than last year’s address.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 8 Recap: Unplugged
item.description: Without internet, the Pitt was even more chaotic than usual. This on a national holiday on which people blow up things for fun.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: Nurse Princess (Kristin Villanueva) had to cover for Dana as the charge nurse for a while. Then the internet went out.

item.title: Jean Widmer, Designer of Celebrated French Graphics, Dies at 96
item.description: His minimalist road signs became a visual hallmark of France’s highways. He also created logos for cultural institutions like the Pompidou Center.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Netflix Backs Out of Bid for Warner Bros., Paving Way for Paramount Takeover
item.description: The move was a stunning development in the long-running corporate battle for the storied media giant.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch, Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount Pictures in Hollywood.

item.title: Teresa de Lauretis, Coiner (and Critic) of Queer Theory, Dies at 87
item.description: She came up with the term as the title of a 1990 conference but saw its later popularity as a little superficial.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: Teresa de Lauretis in 2015. The debut of “queer theory” as a term came in the title of an academic conference she organized and in an associated issue of a feminist journal.

item.title: ‘Scream 7’ Review: Neve Campbell Returns to Face Ghostface
item.description: Ghostface has returned amid a light fog of nostalgia in this reunion for some of the franchise’s most terrified faces, including Neve Campbell’s.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Review: Aya Ogawa’s ‘Meat Suit’ Sits With the Mess of Motherhood
item.description: In Aya Ogawa’s compassionate, sharply comical play, the pastel-pink public image of mommyhood doesn’t stand a chance.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes

item.title: Rose Lesniak, Poet Who Rescued Children and Trained Dogs, Dies at 70
item.description: A magnetic personality, she reinvented herself twice, bringing the same spirit to investigating child abuse and communing with dogs that she did to writing poetry.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Megan Thee Stallion to Step Into Broadway’s ‘Moulin Rouge! The Musical’
item.description: For eight weeks this spring, the popular rapper will be featured as a nightclub impresario in “Moulin Rouge! The Musical.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’ve always believed in pushing myself creatively,” Megan Thee Stallion, who has three Grammys, said in a statement.

item.title: What Belongs in America’s 250th Birthday Time Capsule?
item.description: The federal group organizing the upcoming Semiquincentennial unveiled details of a vessel to be placed near Independence Hall on July 4 and opened in 2276.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:description: The Bicentennial of 1976 set off a craze for time capsules, like this one in Bridgehampton, N.Y., to be opened in 2076.

item.title: Tracey Emin on Love, Loss and Getting Out of ‘My Bed’
item.description: Since the artist was diagnosed with aggressive bladder cancer in 2020, a lot has changed in her life and work. A new show at Tate Modern examines Tracey Emin’s “second life.”
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Stanford and Alice Zoo For The New York Times
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Fast Car’ Changed Luke Combs’s Life. He’s Back for More Hits.
item.description: The country singer helped to usher the genre into the streaming era before taking a step back. On his new album, he wants to go for broke.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli, Jon Caramanica and Jason Nocito
item.media:credit: Jason Nocito for The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Luckiest Man in America’ and More Streaming Gems
item.description: A game-show drama and a documentary valentine to a cult movie queen are among the little treats tucked away on your subscription streaming services this month.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey

item.title: With Bends, Crinkles and a Cool Decor Makeover, Carol Bove Takes the Guggenheim
item.description: She extracts something new from steel, dispelling its aura of brawn. Her signature form is a rumpled ribbon of metal painted to look as soft as suede.
item.dc:creator: Deborah Solomon and Myrthe Giesbers
item.media:credit: Myrthe Giesbers for The New York Times

item.title: Noguchi Envisioned a More Open New York. New York Wasn’t Interested.
item.description: Isamu Noguchi became one of the most successful artists of the 20th century, but the city met his plans for public spaces with indifference.
item.dc:creator: Max Lakin

item.title: ‘Grease 2,’ the Giddy, Raunchy Flop That Brought Us Michelle Pfeiffer
item.description: The highly anticipated 1982 sequel failed to meet expectations at the time but has since charmed an adoring following with its ambitious dance numbers and nonstop ear worms.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: ‘In the Blink of an Eye’ Review: We Are the Future
item.description: These three connected stories about the whole of human history can’t quite sustain the necessary emotional heft.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: In the Blink of an Eye (Movie)

item.title: ‘K-Pops!’ Review: Reconnecting Through Music
item.description: Anderson .Paak directs and stars alongside his real-life son in this film, which offers sometimes charming, if somewhat sterile pleasures.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Idiotka’ Review: She’s a Haute Mess
item.description: A scrappy Russian American seamstress from West Hollywood competes in a fashion design reality show in this clever and earnest indie comedy.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: ‘Ghost Elephants’ Review: Pursuing What Could Be a Dream
item.description: Werner Herzog’s new documentary about the hunt for elephants in Angola focuses less on the animals and more on the pursuers.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: ‘Dreams’ Review: Erotic, but Not Enough Charge
item.description: Jessica Chastain plays a wealthy philanthropist obsessed with an undocumented dancer in this chilly drama.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: Late Night Fixates on How Long Trump Spoke
item.description: “This time, Trump spoke and everyone else fell asleep,” Jimmy Fallon said.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Ann Godoff, a Top Editor and Publisher of Best Sellers, Dies at 76
item.description: Considered an “author’s publisher” at Random House and then Penguin, she cultivated the careers of dozens of celebrated novelists and nonfiction writers.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Ann Godoff at the Random House offices in Manhattan in 1999 with the editor Robert Loomis. She had “a flawless sense of what would sell and what wouldn’t,” the biographer Ron Chernow said.
